Notes: The most common stem is the one ending in*-ā;*ammaiis also reconstructible on the basis of Tam.ammai, Mal.amma, Iru.amme. Kannaḍa forms with-mb-seem to have been reborrowed from Indo-Aryan. The meaning 'mother' is common for almost all dialects, but in some of them the derivative form*ammaihas assumed the meaning 'father' (cf. Tam.ammān_'maternal uncle, wife's father', i. e. 'he-of-mother').

Irula 113. Practically all the Kannada nouns go back to*iḍ-ùk-; the-a-in the second syllable is secondary, which explains the lack of forms like*eḍaku. The few formswithinitiale-(dial. Mal., Tulu) are probably secondary formations as well.
Kas. 218; Zv. Ir. 606. Tulu preserves the original suffixless form.
